issue.title: Help test and implement the markdown custom editor preview

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body: ## BackgroundrnUsers would like the markdown preview to be opened when they open a markdown file. Feature requests #2766 and #54776 track a few different use cases, but the main one we are interested in right now is: when I open a markdown file, instead of opening the normal text editor, the markdown preview is opened instead. rnrnThis can now be implemented using custom editors: #77131 rnrn## Current StatusrnThe current insiders (1.41) contributes a custom editor for the markdown preview. It is not enabled by default by can be selected by running `View: Reopen with` with a markdown file open. You can also use the following setting to always open markdown files in preview mode instead of in the editor:rnrn```jsonrn// u2757ufe0fExperimental: this setting may be removed or changed at anytimern'workbench.experimental.editorAssociations': [rn    {rn        'viewType': 'vscode.markdown.preview.editor',rn        'filenamePattern': '*.md'rn    }rn]rn```rnrnThe custom editor should look identical to the existing markdown preview.rnrn## How to helprnThe markdown custom editor needs testing and polish before it can be shipped. We are looking for the community to drive this. I've created this issue to collect feedback and discussion of this work.rnrnBefore we ship this feature, we need to make sure that custom editor based previews work as existing VS Code users would expect and work with the existing markdown preview's behavior and settings. This issue is intentionally open ended. Try playing around with the custom editor based markdown preview and exploring what works as expected and what doesn'trnrnSome starting areas to focus on:rnrn- How do custom editor based previews Integrate with existing markdown previews? rn- Switching editors. rn- Scrolling.rn- Links. (For example, where do links open?)rn- Markdown security settings.rn

issue.title: Workspace shell permissions are not remembered in multi-root workspaces

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body: My workflow requires the use of cygwin in particular workspaces, so I have my *workspace settings* set up to default to cygwin for the integrated terminal. The 'Do you allow this workspace to modify your terminal shell?' comes up *every single time* I open this workspace, which is absolutely painful (requires using the mouse) when I *always* allow it. rnrn![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1386467/64657849-593d5f80-d474-11e9-9afe-7b25605e6b42.png)rnrnThis wouldn't be such an issue if it just showed up the first time I opened vscode, but it also shows up every time I duplicate the workspace as well (which I do regularly).rnrn![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1386467/64657956-cd780300-d474-11e9-9783-9e929e2f13a4.png)rnrnIs it possible to get an option to 'Remember for this workspace', or at least to not ask every time I duplicate a workspace if I had already allowed/disallowed?

issue.title: Help webview extensions add a Content Security Policy

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description: The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.rnOur goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

issue.body: Many webview extensions do not currently set a [content security policy](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP). All webviews (even very simple ones) should set a content security policy. This is not a immediate security problem but a content security policy helps to limit the potential impact of content injections and is generally a good measure for defense in depth. rnrnI've put together this initial list of extensions that create webviews that seem not to have a content security policy (there may be false positives). If you are feeling like a security hero, **consider helping these extensions out by submitting a PR that adds a restrictive content security policy to their webviews**. [Here's our documentation to help you get started](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/extension-guides/webview#content-security-policy).rnrnLet me know if an extension has been fixed or was incorrectly flaggedrnrn---rnrn**Key**rnrn- u2757ufe0f- Confirmed and issue openedrn- u2714ufe0f - issue.title: The 'Local image' preview fails to render on Windows when both files are in the same directory on:  a  based network share; the root of a drive

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body: <!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->rnrn<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->rn- VS Code version: Code 1.22.2 (3aeede733d9a3098f7b4bdc1f66b63b0f48c1ef9, 2018-04-12T16:38:45.278Z)rn- OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16299rnrnI tried:rnrn- searching through the existing open issues but could not find a matching onern- specifying the issue below as specific as I couldrnrn# Image preview testrnrnSteps to reproduce:rnrn1. Download <https://via.placeholder.com/350x150.png> to a local directoryrn2. Save this text in the same directory as `test.md` (see permutations below)rn3. Open `test.md` in Visual Studio Code 1.22 or higher (tested on Windows 10 Pro x64 or Mac High Sierra)rn4. Enable the markdown preview windowrnrnThe 'Local image' preview fails to render on Windows when both files are in the same directory on:rnrn- a  `` based network sharern- the root of a drivernrnThe 'Local image' preview succeeds on Windows when the files are on a regular drive letter in a subdirectory (even when the drive is pointing to a network share).rnrnThe 'URL image' preview always succeeds (when there is an active internet connection)rnrn## URL imagernrn![URL image](https://via.placeholder.com/350x150.png)rnrn## Local imagernrn![Local image](350x150.png)rnrnThe 'Local image' fails when the files are stored at:rnrn- `tsclienttmp`rn- `tsclienttmpdirectory`rn- `localhostc$ProgramDataTemp`rn- `T:`  after a `net use T: tsclienttmp`rn- `C:`rn- a MacrnrnThe 'Local image' succeeds when the files are stored at:rnrn- `C:ProgramDataTemp`rn- `X:ProgramDataTemp` after a `net use X: localhostC$`rn- `T:directory`  after a `net use T: tsclienttmp`rnrnPreview of failurernrn> rn![screenshot 2018-04-23 15 16 36](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2033367/39129398-b0082410-470a-11e8-95c1-6030acbd4854.png)rnrnrn<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->rnDoes this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yesrnrn<details>rn<summary>System Info</summary>rnrn|Item|Value|rn|---|---|rn|CPUs|Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2670 v3 @ 2.30GHz (2 x 2300)|rn|Memory (System)|8.00GB (4.37GB free)|rn|Process Argv|C:Program FilesMicrosoft VS CodeCode.exe|rn|Screen Reader|no|rn|VM|100%|rnrn</details><details><summary>Extensions (2)</summary>rnrnExtension|Author (truncated)|Versionrn---|---|---rnvscode-markdownlint|Dav|0.14.1rnmarkdown-all-in-one|yzh|1.2.0rnrnrn</details>rn<!-- generated by issue reporter -->rn

issue.title: Git diff ignores language configured encoding

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body: <!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->rnrn<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->rn- VSCode Version: 1.22.2rn- OS Version: Windows 10 x64 version 1709rnrnVersion 1.22.2rnCommit 3aeede733d9a3098f7b4bdc1f66b63b0f48c1ef9rnDate 2018-04-12T16:38:45.278ZrnShell 1.7.12rnRenderer 58.0.3029.110rnNode 7.9.0rnArchitecture x64rnrnSteps to Reproduce:rnrn1. Setup user settings according to thisrn```jsonrn    '[json]': {rn        'files.encoding': 'windows1252'rn    },rn    'files.encoding': 'utf8',rn```rn2. Initialize a git reporn3. Create a test.json file with the following content (win1252 encoding) and commitrn```jsonrn{rnt'some-test': 'Some content with win1252 characters',rnt'content': 'u00e3u00e7u00c7~'au00e0u00e1',rnt'test': 'regular chars'rn}rn```rn4. Change only line 4 for something (like this)rn```jsonrn{rnt'some-test': 'Some content with win1252 characters',rnt'content': 'u00e3u00e7u00c7~'au00e0u00e1',rnt'test': 'regular chars test'rn}rn```rn5. Check the git diff. Will report changes on lines 3 and 4 because will convert to utf8 before diff, ignoring the language encoding configuration (win1252)rn6. Perform a git diff to see the difference and how it should work properly (only line 4 reported as changed):rn```shrn$ git diff test.jsonrndiff --git a/test.json b/test.jsonrnindex 638f49c..b19527f 100644rn--- a/test.jsonrn+++ b/test.jsonrn@@ -1,5 +1,5 @@rn {rn        'some-test': 'Some content with win1252 characters',rn        'content': '<E3><E7><C7>~'a<E0><E1>',rn-       'test': 'regular chars'rn+       'test': 'regular chars test'^Mrn }rn```rn7. Issue won't happen if my user settings are like this:rn```jsonrn    '[json]': {rn        'files.encoding': 'windows1252'rn    },rn    'files.encoding': 'windows1252',rn```rnrn<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->rnDoes this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yesrn

issue.title: 'Download Now' button should respect the used installation method on Linux

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

issue.body: ### Issue TypernrnBugrnrn### Descriptionrnrn> __Edit:__ Originally this issue was specifically about the `.deb` installation method, but since this problem is not specific to it, I edited the issue to be more general.rnrn#### How to reproducernrn1. Install (an outdated version of) VS Code using one of the installation methods.rn2. Open VSCode and wait for the `(1)` to appear on the settings icon.rn3. Click on the settings icon and then on **Download Now**.rnrn#### Expected behaviorrnrnVSCode starts the download of the latest version's file (when the `.tar.gz` was used to install VS Code) or instructs the user to run an update through the relevant package manager.rnrn#### Actual behaviorrnrnVS Code always starts the download of the latest version's `.tar.gz` file.rnrn### Possible solutionrnrnVS Code could check what type of download was used to install and behave differently based on that.rnChecking whether a `.deb` was used could look something like this:rnrn```tsrnimport { spawn } from 'child_process';rnrnexport function isDebInstallation(): Promise<boolean> {rn  return new Promise(resolve => {rn    spawn('dpkg', ['--list', 'code']).on('close', code => {rn      resolve(code === 0);rn    });rn  });rn}rn```rnrnAnother option would be to include the information about what installation method was used in the release.rnrn### VS Code InfornrnVS Code version: Code 1.20.0 (c63189deaa8e620f650cc28792b8f5f3363f2c5b, 2018-02-07T17:10:15.949Z)rnOS version: Linux x64 4.13.0-32-genericrnrn<details>rn<summary>System Info</summary>rnrn|Item|Value|rn|---|---|rn|CPUs|Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-4590 CPU @ 3.30GHz (4 x 3300)|rn|Load (avg)|1, 1, 1|rn|Memory (System)|15.61GB (10.31GB free)|rn|Process Argv|/usr/share/code/code .|rn|Screen Reader|no|rn|VM|0%|rnrn</details>rnReproduces without extensions

issue.title: Allow suggested list for Run>Task... to be modified
issue.body: First off this is similar to another request https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/30419 but I think different enough it deserves its own post.rnrnI have so many tasks, most of which are just variations of another....rnrnI find the recently used suggestions to mostly hinder my experience as I have to keep searching the list for the task I would like to run.rnrnI would like to see the ability to set the number of 'recently used tasks'. This way I can limit it to only show 2 or 3.rnrnThe other configuration I would like is to be able to always show the tasks in alphabetical order.rnrnCurrently, the suggested task list is formatted as such:rnrn```rn---------------------------------------------rnrecently used tasks (sorted by last used)rn---------------------------------------------rnremaining declared tasks (sorted alphabetically)rn---------------------------------------------rndetected tasksrn---------------------------------------------rn```rnrnExample:rnrn```rn---------------------------------------------rnbuild-x-debug             recently used tasksrnserve-y-debugrnbuild-y-debugrnupdate-majorrnbuild-y-livernserve-x-debugrnbuild-all-prodrnserve-x-livernbuild-x-livernupdate-minorrnbuild-y-prodrnbuild-y-prodrn---------------------------------------------rnbuild-all-test                configure tasksrnbuild-x-prodrnserve-y-livernupdate-patchrn---------------------------------------------rnnpm: install                   detected tasksrnnpm: e2ern---------------------------------------------rn```rnrnIn other words if a task is the recently used list it will not be in the centre list, ideally I think it would be beneficial to have this centre list always contain every task that is defined that way you can skim the recently used list but if you miss it there, you will know that it is always going to be in the same spot in that centre list. Along with limiting the number of recently used tasks I believe this will make the suggested list much more usable.rnrn```rn---------------------------------------------rnrecently used tasks (sorted by last used)rn---------------------------------------------rnall declared tasks (sorted alphabetically)rn---------------------------------------------rndetected tasksrn---------------------------------------------rn```rnrnExample:rnrn```rn---------------------------------------------rnbuild-x-debug             recently used tasksrnserve-y-debugrnbuild-y-debugrn---------------------------------------------rnbuild-all-prod                configure tasksrnbuild-all-testrnbuild-x-debugrnbuild-x-livernbuild-x-prodrnbuild-y-debugrnbuild-y-livernbuild-y-prodrnserve-x-debugrnserve-x-livernserve-y-debugrnserve-y-livernupdate-majorrnupdate-minorrnupdate-patchrn---------------------------------------------rnnpm: install                   detected tasksrnnpm: e2ern---------------------------------------------rn```rnrn

issue.title: Git: Add command for git stash drop
issue.body: Issue Type: BugrnrnWhen poping a stash and there are merge conflicts between the stash and current code, even after the conflict is resolved, the pop'ed stash isn't dropped from the stash list.rnThe only way to drop a stash in vscode, AFAIK, is by successfully merging a stash, meaning that if a stash is no longer relevant (only conflicts, never merged), it can never be dropped from within vscode, only by a terminal command.rnrnmy suggestion is: when there are conflicts, let the user choose whether to resolve the conflicts or to just drop the stash.rnrnVS Code version: Code 1.35.1 (c7d83e57cd18f18026a8162d042843bda1bcf21f, 2019-06-12T14:30:02.622Z)rnOS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763rnrnrn

issue.title: Status zoom button should be a IStatusbarEntry
issue.body: I noticed that [`ZoomStatusbarItem`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/f5bc332/src/vs/workbench/browser/parts/editor/resourceViewer.ts#L237) is a `IStatusbarItem`. This one is typically when you need full control over the rendering of the item, but it seems you are only using text. I suggest to change this to `IStatusbarEntry` and use `IStatusbarService#addEntry()` to show and hide it dynamically. You can also update properties dynamically on the returned object.rnrnI had to push https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/4eb7879ae17b2218b0d7c965040313b12894cdd7 because I noticed that some style changes broke the visual appearance of this item. We could avoid issues like these in the future by switching to the same model e.g. extensions are using too.rnrnIs there anything that blocks us from going there? I could not see anything when I was checking the implementation quickly.

issue.body: Hi,rnrnI would like a way to access the path to the current workspace in the git hooks.rnrnMy use case is for running a precommit hook in a 'monorepo'.rnrnLet's say I have something like:rn.rnu251cu2500u2500 .git/rnu251cu2500u2500 README.mdrnu251cu2500u2500 ProjectA/rn|   u251cu2500u2500 CMakeLists.txtrn|   u2514u2500u2500 src/rnu251cu2500u2500 ProjectB/rn|   u251cu2500u2500 CMakeLists.txtrn|   u2514u2500u2500 src/rnrn'ProjectB' is opened in vscode, but when the hook is executed the current dir is the root of the monorepo(which is the expected behavior).rnrnIn the hook script(Python but not relevant), I have currently no way to know on which project I am working. Without knowing if I am 'ProjectA' or 'ProjectB', I can not compile & test & clang-tidy & etc the changes.rnrnI have printed the whole `os.environ` in the hook's code, and I see nothing useful.rnBut maybe I am missing another way to do what I want?rnrnThe solution could be as simple as adding a new VSCODE_WORKSPACE_FOLDER var to the environment.rnrnPS: I obviously could try & compile each project, but this not a proper solution.rn

Install a typescript project with typescript version `>= 3.2.0` (earlier version don't support this way to extend node_module package.rn2. Create a tsconfig file.rn3. Make tsconfig file extend from a node module, e.g. `{ 'extends': '@my-team/team-tsconfig' }`.rn4. issue.title: vscode-tscancellation- files being created without limit.
issue.body: <!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->rn<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->rnrn<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->rn- VSCode Version: 1.32.3rn- OS Version: Windows 10rnrnSteps to Reproduce:rnrn1. Use VS Code with TypeScript for any amount of timern2. There is no step 2.rnrnDoes this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/NornSeems to be caused by core TypeScript support.rnrnOK so this has been reported before. #54671, #53423, #61935, #28970, probably more. I got bored of checking. Technically this report is a duplicate, but since the issue keeps getting ignored, here we all are.rnrnEach time the report is closed, and we're told it's by design.rnrnWell I'm telling you it's a terrible design. I mean, quite aside from the issue of using a file to signal that a request has been cancelled (surely there's some better IPC mechanism that could be used for that? A named pipe, an event, a signal, a socket, a domain socket, anything), there's the minor issue of VSCode never actually deleting the files.rnrn@mjbvz seems to be of the [opinion](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/53423#issuecomment-401842492) that the files will be cleaned up by the operating system. And that might be true on a Linux machine with files created under /tmp, because /tmp should get clobbered each time you reboot. It might even be true of macOS, I don't know.rnrnWhat I do know is that it's not true of Windows. %temp% does not get clobbered automatically. A file that's created in %temp% is going to stay there until it's manually removed. It's true that the Disk Cleanup utility can remove some files from %temp% and can be scheduled, but typically nothing is ever removed from %temp% by the operating system. Applications are meant to tidy up after themselves. VSCode is failing to do so.rnrnIf VSCode were using raw win32 then the obvious answer would be to open the files with delete-on-close, so they'd get tidied up automatically. But I don't know if Electron apps have the ability to do that.rn

issue.title: Difftool Commit Message now removes whitespace from default template
issue.body: I posted this concern on [stack overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55153030/does-the-source-control-feature-have-an-option-to-include-whitespace-in-template) because I was unsure if it was a feature already present and I was unaware of, but it has been silent and I'm pretty sure now this is a feature request.rnrnAfter one of the most recent updates, the message editor has begun ignoring whitespace inside my git commit template. Having the whitespace was preferred for my use case, and now without it, I get the warning that that what it thinks is my subject line is now beyond the character limit. I enjoy having the character limit warning, so I don't want to turn it off. I just want the editor to be able to see and keep whitespace if I prefer. Is it possible?rnrnIf you need an example of why someone would prefer whitespace, see the link above for to my stack exchange example.

issue.title: Accessibility improvements for finding in files
issue.body:
Issue Type: BugrnrnCC: @isidornrnrnHi,rnrnSome parts of the workflow for searching within a file with ctrl+f aren't that accessible. As a demonstration, have a blank editor with the following contents:rnrn```rnhello worldrngoodbye worldrn```rnrnFrom the top of the file, when pressing ctrl+f and typing `world`, visually the first occurance is highlighted, but no screen reader feedback is provided at all. So my instinct is to press enter, which of course brings me to the second match instead. rnNext when on the second line, perform the same search. By default, it wraps you back to the beginning of the file if no more matches are found, which is doubly confusing due to the lack of feedback.rnrnI expect to hear something similar to how its announced in the results view in project-wide search, but less verbose. E.g, '1/2: Found 'world' at 9:20 with text: 'rnrnSimilar context should also be provided when moving using f3 and shift+f3, but haven't figured out what the best messages would be.rnrnOn a related note, I'm also pondering whether disabling such wrap-around by default if a screen reader is detected would be better. It is obvious that this has happened visually, but unless enough context is provided, it can be confusing.rnrnVS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.32.0-insider (804373ac4d5c84e96c8086cee5b9be132df88837, 2019-03-01T18:22:35.336Z)rnOS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134rnrn

issue.title: 'Save all and commit' dialog should stage before committing
issue.body:
rnIssue Type: Bugrnrn1. Open or create a project that uses Git source control.rn2. Create or change some files and stage those changes.rn3. Change a file without saving it.rn4. Try to make a commit.rnrnThis will bring up a dialog asking how to make the commit, which includes options to cancel, commit, or save all and commit.rnrnThe nature of the dialog suggests that the file will be included in the commit when you save, which is true if you have no staged files. But when you have staged files, the newly-saved files should be staged as well in order to be included in the commit.rnrnExpected behavior: Files saved with this dialog should be staged for inclusion in the commit.rnrnActual behavior: The commit is made without staging changes in the file.rnrnVS Code version: Code 1.31.1 (1b8e8302e405050205e69b59abb3559592bb9e60, 2019-02-12T02:20:54.427Z)rnOS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763rnrn

issue.title: TypeScript task detection is not cross-platform
issue.body:
Issue Type: BugrnrnIf your `tsconfig.json` is in a subfolder, the folder path has to match the system file separator ( on Windows, / on Mac/Linux) in order for it to work.rnrnSteps to Reproduce:rnrn1. Create a project with a folder in it.rn2. Put tsconfig.json in the subfolder along with a test TypeScript file.rn3. Create a build task for that tsconfig.json. On Windows it will get a backslash, on Mac/Linux a forward slash.rn4. Switch the slash to that of the opposite platform.rn5. Note that now you can't build that task, and that instead you get an error similar to the following:rnrn```rnError: The typescript task detection didn't contribute a task for the following configuration:rn{rn 'label': 'tsc-api',rn 'type': 'typescript',rn 'tsconfig': 'api/tsconfig.json',rn 'option': 'watch',rn 'options': {rn 'cwd': '${workspaceFolder}/api'rn },rn 'promptOnClose': true,rn 'problemMatcher': [rn '$tsc-watch'rn ],rn 'group': 'build'rn}rnThe task will be ignored.rn```rnrnThe only workaround I've found is to create TWO tasks for each desired task, where one has forward slashes and the other backslashes. But a recent VS Code update made a warning box appear for those configurations _every time I build or debug_, which is annoying. Please address the underlying issue.rnrnHonestly, this would be _yet another situation_ where simply using forward slashes _all the time_ would fix everything. This would also fix, for instance:rnrnhttps://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/35593rnrn...a bug that's been around for a year and a half now. :(rnrnVS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.32.0-insider (003521e715f2dbcf4f98be99a923097505859954, 2019-02-15T06:16:29.903Z)rnOS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134rnrn

issue.title: VSCode git sync fails because of tags

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
Issue Type: BugrnrnI'm having an issue with the git sync (which uses `--tags`). The project I work on relies on certain tags in order to do some deployments to QA servers. The tags are always the same name but they're constantly pointing to different refs so I get an error in VSCode when I try to sync. Output log:rnrn```rn> git pull --tags origin features/LITE-1050-more-options-for-showinfo-paramrn> git show HEAD:imports/startup/client/scripts/components/sections-layout-cards.component.jsrnFrom github.com:mapmelabs/mapme-litern * branch features/LITE-1050-more-options-for-showinfo-param -> FETCH_HEADrn ! [rejected] qa2 -> qa2 (would clobber existing tag)rn> git show HEAD:imports/startup/client/scripts/components/sections-layout-cards.component.jsrn```rnrnIn order to 'fix' it, I need to run `git pull --tags -f` and VSCode sync works until the tags change again. Since I don't need to pull tags, **is there any way to instruct VSCode not to use `--tags` when it pulls?** I already looked in the settings but haven't found anything.rnThis has been a big drawback for me lately. Thanks.rnrnVS Code version: Code 1.30.2 (61122f88f0bf01e2ac16bdb9e1bc4571755f5bd8, 2019-01-07T22:48:31.260Z)rnOS version: Darwin x64 16.7.0rnrn

issue.title: Show 'clear search' in settings-UI even when matched settings are found
issue.body: ## ProblemrnCurrently when one types a term in the search-bar of the settings-UI and no matching settings are found then a *Clear Search* option appears which deletes the term in the search-bar if clicked. However, this option does not appear when matching settings are found. If one wants now to remove the term from the search-bar one has to manually select the typed term and press the delete-button.rnrn## SolutionrnIt would be more convenient if there always would be a 'Delete Search'-Button. This could be a little *X* symbol on the right of the search-bar.rnrn## BonusrnCurrently when the *Clear Search* option is clicked the search-term is deleted but the search-bar loses focus. It would be more convenient if the search-bar would get the focus such that one could immediately start typing the new search-term.rn

issue.body: While creating a user snippet, the rule must be like this:rnrn```jsonrn'example': {rnt'prefix': 'example',rnt'body': [rntt'line 1',rntt'line 2'rnt],rnt'description': 'A single line description'rn}rn```rnrnIf I want to show a lot of description, I must write a huge string which includes many escape characters like this:rnrn```jsonrn'toctree': {rnt'prefix': '.. toctree::',rnt'body': [rntt'.. toctree::',rntt'$0'rnt],rnt'description': 'A toctree item, have these options:nt:maxdepth: parant:caption: pararnnt:numbered:nt:titlesonly:nt:glob:nt:reversed:nt:hidden:nt:includehidden:',rnt'scope': 'text.restructuredtext'rn},rn```rnrnIt maybe a good idea that `description` option receive a list value, like the `body`:rnrn```jsonrn'toctree': {rnt'prefix': '.. toctree::',rnt'body': [rntt'.. toctree::',rntt'$0'rnt],rnt'description': [rntt'A toctree item, have these options:',rntt':maxdepth: para',rntt':caption: para',rntt':numbered:',rntt':titlesonly:',rntt':glob:',rntt':reversed:',rntt':hidden:',rntt':includehidden:'rnt],rnt'scope': 'text.restructuredtext'rn},rn```

issue.title: Strict Null Checking Part II: The Testing!
issue.body: A sequel to October's hit: #60565, *Strict Null Checking VS Code*rnrn## BackstoryrnrnWe are incrementally working to enable TypeScript's [strict null checks](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/release-notes/typescript-2-0.html) for the core of VS Code: #60565. Strict null checks help to catch silly programming mistakes and generally enforce a more explicit and safer coding style. Enabling strict null checks should reduce the number of undefined access exceptions VS Code users hit and help VS Code contributors move more quicklyrnrn## This timernrnWith #60565, we have already migrated over 800 files to be strict null checked but have not yet enabled strict null for many of our unit tests. That's where you can help out.rnrnThis item tracks enabling strict null checks for the `*.test.ts` files in the core VS Code codebase (under [`./src`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/tree/master/src)). This work can be done on a file-by-file basis and should be fairly straightforward. If you are interested in contributing to VS Code, enabling strict null checking for a few test files is a great way to help out and a great way to learn more about the codebase.rnrn## How to contributernrn1. Setup a VS Code development environment if you have not already done so: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contributernrn1. Make sure you are on the latest commit of VS Code from master.rnrn1. Pick a strict null check eligible test file from the list posted below. rnrn1.  Add the file in the `files` section of the [`src/tsconfig.strictNullChecks.json`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/tsconfig.strictNullChecks.json) file in the VS Code codebase.rnrn    ```jsoncrn    'files': [rn        ...,rnrn        // To avoid merge conflicts, try to add your file in roughly sorted orderrn        './vs/base/test/common/keyCodes.test.ts',rnrn        ...rn    ]rn    ```rnrn2. Run `yarn strict-null-check`,  or `yarn strict-null-check -- --watch` to run the null checks in watch mode rnrn3. Fix null check related errors. See the guidelines below for more details. Some files may only have a single error while others may have hundreds. We welcome all incremental fixesrnrn4. [Run the tests](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#automated-testing) to make sure they still passrnrn5. Submit a PR with your change. Try to keep each PR to converting a single filernrn## General guidelines for fixing strict null errors in testsrnrn- Annotate nullable types and fix simple type errorsrnrn- Use the[ `!` not null assertion](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/release-notes/typescript-2-0.html#non-null-assertion-operator) to skip null checking when testing APIs that may return undefined. For example, if we were testing the `divide` function:rnrn    ```tsrn    function divide(a: number, b: number): { result: number } | undefined {rn        return b === 0 ? undefined : { result: a / b };rn    }rnrn    test('div tests', () => {rn        // Normally strict null checks would complain about accessing `.result` sincern        // `divide` may return undefined. Use the ! not null assertion to suppress thisrn        // since the test will fail anyways if we try accessing `undefined.result`. rn        assert.strictEquals(divide(1, 2)!.result, 0.5);rn    });rn    ```rnrnu2757ufe0f  If you aren't sure about how to fix a given error, just ask or leave it unfixed. We can only merge PRs that have a passing build so if you do skip any errors, make sure your PR does not actually add the file to `src/tsconfig.strictNullChecks.json`.rnrn(Also please do not close this issue in your PR. This issue will be left open until we have enable strict null checking for all tests)rnrnrnrn

issue.title: Bug: Markdown, U+2028, and 'Go to Symbol in File...'
issue.body: Suppose you take the following file, except that the line containing `foo` also contains `U+2028` somewhere in it.rnrn```markdownrn# Arn- foornrn# Brn- barrn```rnrn`vscode` will render `U+2028` as a question mark in a diamond, and the list of symbols that appear in the 'Go to Symbol in File...'  popup will be shifted (by the number of `U+2028` characters present in the file). Screenshots that illustrate this are below.rnrn![screen shot 2018-11-25 at 19 03 03](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10088591/48983289-c9951300-f0e4-11e8-83dc-f527226c95f7.png)rnrn![screen shot 2018-11-25 at 19 03 08](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10088591/48983290-c9951300-f0e4-11e8-93cc-ccd5b77478c4.png)rnrn(Why did this come up? If you triple-click 'u2028felicita - hej!u2028' in [this link](https://www.residentadvisor.net/reviews/22851), and paste it into `vscode`, it actually has a pair of enclosing `U+2028` characters. It seems unique to that page...)

issue.title: Docs for formatOnSave are unclear
issue.body: <!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->rn<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->rnrn<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->rn- VSCode Version: rnVersion: 1.29.0-insiderrnCommit: d43f6cb9947c57a3254b556e69aeacc2b2025184rnDate: 2018-11-02T15:56:43.302ZrnElectron: 2.0.12rnChrome: 61.0.3163.100rnNode.js: 8.9.3rnV8: 6.1.534.41rnArchitecture: x64rn(Also occurring on my non-insiders 1.28.2 install)rnrn- OS Version: 4.18.16-arch1-1-ARCHrnrnSteps to Reproduce:rnrn1. Set settings.json to: ```rn{rn    'files.autoSave': 'onFocusChange',rn    'editor.formatOnSave': truern}``` rn2. Install the prettier extensionrn3. Open a javascript file and edit it in a way that will change when formattedrn4. Switch focus to another windowrnrnThe file will auto save as expected, but it also formats. Based on the description of the `editor.formatOnSave` setting which says 'the file must not be auto-saved' I would expect the file not to be formatted after this save.rnrnThe same issue happens when `'files.autoSave': 'onWindowChange'` is set. When `'file.autoSave': 'afterDelay'` is set it works as expected (saves without format).rnrnI also tested using the Rust (rls) extension to format a Rust file and the same issue occurred.rnrnI prefer to auto save on focus change but I do not want the file formatted unless I manually save. The description of `editor.formatOnSave`  leads me to believe that with these two settings I will get that behavior but I do not. Either the behavior should be changed to only format on a manual save (which I believe is the intended behavior) or the description should be changed to clarify that the file must not be auto saved after delay (if that is actually the intended behavior).rnrn<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->rnDoes this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: N/A because the issue depends on a formatting extension being installed. It does occur when all extensions other than prettier are disabled.rn

issue.title: Git fails to checkout remote branch with the same name as a local branch
issue.body: <!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> rn<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->rnrn<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->rn- VSCode Version: 1.29.0-insider (user setup)rn- OS Version: Windows 10 10.0.17134rnrn**more details - entire help entry**rnVersion: 1.29.0-insider (user setup)rnCommit: 931c22033db3cc8d5dff265889307ed4076ac2d3rnDate: 2018-10-12T05:17:15.739ZrnElectron: 2.0.11rnChrome: 61.0.3163.100rnNode.js: 8.9.3rnV8: 6.1.534.41rnArchitecture: x64rnrnSteps to Reproduce:rnrn1. open *vscode* with a git controlled folder.rn2. from any branch select the scm icon in status bar to checkout a different branch and select origin/master in the command pallette popup while on say developrnrn<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->rnDoes this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/NornYesrnrn*this is the error I recieve*rn![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2422222/46920227-4e4e2680-cfa8-11e8-92e7-789379560ece.png)rnrn**Here is the git log**rn```rn> git checkout -q --track origin/masterrnfatal: A branch named 'master' already exists.rn> git fetchrn> git status -z -urn> git symbolic-ref --short HEADrn> git rev-parse developrn> git rev-parse --symbolic-full-name develop@{u}rn> git rev-list --left-right develop...refs/remotes/origin/developrn> git for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname) --sort -committerdatern> git remote --verbosern```  rnrnI normally do not use the insiders build but I installed it to test this out.rnrnThere may be a issue with my git for windows configuration and not vscode.rnI recently updated my git for windows install and this problem started after the update.rnrnIf I simply execute `git checkout master` then the checkout works as expected it seems the problem only happens when using vscode scm features.

issue.title: Git: Delete Branch command should support multiple choice

milestone.title: Backlog

issue.body: The `Git: Delete Branch` command at the moment supports deleting only one branch at a time.rnrnMost of the time I use this feature is delete all the stale branches I have either from working on old features or the branches that get created when doing PR reviews.rnrnHaving a multiple choice for this command would make it easier to clean up the mess :)

issue.title: Git: Separate the commit length limit of subject line and description lines
issue.body: Since VS Code 1.28 we have a new `git.inputValidationLength` to set the commit length limit, but I think the subject line and the description lines should have different length settings, as @mark-wiemer  mentioned in #56481.rnrn[This article](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/) says the subject line is preferably limited 50 characters, and the description lines are 72 characters per line. Also, GitHub web UI displays a warning message if your commit subject line is more than 50 characters.rnrn![screenshot_2018-10-09](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16081977/46666060-3b2e0600-cbf8-11e8-893c-4d62679cf877.png)rnrnHow about something like `git.subjectValidationLength` and `git.descriptionValidationLength`?

issue.title: Enable separeate preview modes for Search & Replace results
issue.body: <!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->rnrn<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->rnrnThere is a setting called `'workbench.editor.enablePreview'`, which I currently have set to `false`, mainly because I use my keyboard arrows to navigate through files in the file explorer, and it annoys me that when I open a file pressing Enter, it opens it in preview mode (I would have to double click on it with my mouse to open it and keep it, but as I said I am barely using my mouse).rnrnHowever, when I am watching my Search & Replace results, I don't like that every file with a search result opens when I navigate through it. After I finish my search, I end up with a bunch of open editors that I am not going to use anymore. Here is where I would like to use the preview mode.rnrnTo summarize, I would like to have the preview modes separately for each context: something like  `'workbench.editor.enablePreviewFromExplorer'` and `'workbench.editor.enablePreviewFromSearch'`. There is currently a `'workbench.editor.enablePreviewFromQuickOpen'`, which I find very useful.

issue.title: [loc][Query] Suggestion to reduce number of placeholder in resource 'breakpointHasCondition'
issue.body: For string below our translator suggested that it would be a lot easier to localize this resource without having to work with so many placeholders, as from we can see, placeholder {2} is going to get replaced with only two words. Can you please check this suggestion and let us know your opinion? Thanks!rnrn**Original comment**rn{0} and {1} are not a big problem if the gender of the word is as clear as in this case and if the translation for the respective word will be filled in for the tag. **However, since {2} is a verb, it would be better to remove the placeholder and to fill in the word as it used to be.**rnI have found a temporary solution for this sentence now, but I cannot judge how fine it will work if the placeholders get filled in since this highly depends on what will be filled in for them (especially for {2}). In general, it would not be good to use 'enabling' or 'disabling' in a German sentence.rnrn**Context**rnsrc/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugEditorContribution:English (en):plaintext:breakpointHasConditionrnrn**Resource**rnvs_workbench_parts_debugrnrn**String text**rnThis {0} has a {1} that will get lost on remove. Consider {2} the {0} instead.rnrn[**Code**](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/15b78a8c970844112106d918748fd1e5cbd38d66/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugEditorContribution.ts#L206)rn```javascriptrnthis.dialogService.show(severity.Info, nls.localize('breakpointHasCondition', 'This {0} has a {1} that will get lost on remove. Consider {2} the {0} instead.',rnttbreakpointType.toLowerCase(),rnttlogPoint ? nls.localize('message', 'message') : nls.localize('condition', 'condition'),rnttdisable ? nls.localize('disabling', 'disabling') : nls.localize('enabling', 'enabling')rn```

issue.title: Respect global .gitignore when searching
issue.body: The global .gitignore file, aka git config `core.excludesfile` setting should be used when searching, just like the local .gitignore file is.rnrnCurrently files/folders will be ignored if they are in the local .gitignore, but not if they are only in the global git ignore.rnrn#49239 asked about this feature, but it was incorrectly closed.rn

issue.body: <!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> rn<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->rnrn<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->rn- VSCode Version: 1.25.1rn- OS Version: Windows 7 UltimaternrnSteps to Reproduce:rnrn1. Create project.rn2. Commit files to Git.rn3. Change indent.rn4. Stage changes (whole file).rn5. Go to staged version of file.rn6. Select indented section.rn7. Right-click and `Unstage Selected Ranges`rn8. The indent will remain.rnrn<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->rnDoes this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: YesrnrnThis appears to be due to the `Stage/Unstage Selected Ranges` using the diff editor.rnrnDisabling the setting makes it work as expected: `'diffEditor.ignoreTrimWhitespace': false,`rn

With the following minimal code sample:rnrn```tsrnclass FooBar {rn    public baz(str: string);rn    public baz(v: number);rn    public baz(v: any) {rnrn    }rnrn}rnrnconst f = new FooBar();rnf.bazrn```rnrn2. Attempt to navigate to the next override definition by pressing the up arrow on the keyboard.rnrnExpected Results:rnrn* Autocomplete dialog cycles to the last override definition.rnrnActual Results:rnrn* Autocomplete window disappears.rnrnDoes this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: YesrnrnExample:rnrn![vscode_bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1039449/43005385-b2ea2e22-8c00-11e8-9867-d4028d4ee311.gif)

issue.title: Git Stash Apply
issue.body: I've attempted to find any other requests for this but didn't seem to see any.rnrnAt the moment the CVS context menu shows:rn![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/238480/42658519-dd031a4c-8625-11e8-9eaf-1815fed537b6.png)rnrnOnly 'Pop latest stash' and 'Pop stash...' are visible.rnrnIs it possible to change the default stash behaviour to 'apply' rather than 'pop'? Additionally, is it possible to add two lines under 'Pop stash...' for the same actions, just using apply:rn * Apply latest stashrn * Apply stash...rnrnI just lost a few hours and considerable amount of hair when a popped stash was deleted. I then had to sift through `git fsck --lost-found` doing `git show <shahash>` on each `dangling commit <shahash>`. Having 'Apply stash...' easily accessible might be nicer.

issue.title: Focus search results list
issue.body: When I am paging through the search results list, and after I have moved focus to the editor, I would like to be able to move focus back to the search result list, so I can continue to page through the results using my arrow keys.rnrnUsing 'focus into side bar' will focus the input. Perhaps it should instead return focus to the last element within the side bar to have focus.rnrnI am aware of the 'focus next/previous search result' commands, however this doesn't focus the list per se, it just *selects* the search result to show it in the editor. This is not a replacement for paging the list using the arrow keys, e.g. without focusing the list, it's not possible to replace all in file.rnrnPerhaps a separate command could be provided to give focus to the currently selected search result in the list, e.g.rnrn- 'Search: Focus currently selected result in list'rn- 'Search: Focus list' (and implicitly return focus to the currently selected result)rnrn![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/921609/42376040-9ce2a316-8115-11e8-96be-102527588b84.png)rn

issue.title: Allow disabling the submodule auto detection warning
issue.body: There are some project for which I'm always greeted with a warning like this when opening them:rnrn![](https://i.imgur.com/QifQjGz.png)rnrnThis is a bit annoying, as there's nothing actually 'wrong' - I don't need all submodules to be auto-detected for my workflow. I tried this setting in the hopes that it would get rid of the warning:rnrn```jsonrn'git.detectSubmodules': falsern```rnrnHowever, it doesn't actually get rid of the warning, which seems like a bug, or at least counter-intuitive behavior.rnrnIncreasing `'git.detectSubmodulesLimit'` _does_ work, but as I said, I don't really need all submodules to be auto-detected, I just want the warning to go away, and I'm concerned that this has a performance impact.rnrn__________rnrnVSCode version: rnrn![](https://i.imgur.com/uUq6QBc.png)

issue.title: Git: Delete branch notification should be modal
issue.body: The new notifications pop open at the lower right corner of the editor.  Some command palette actions pop these up with a button that I need to click on to proceed.  In these cases, I have to move my mouse from the top center of the window down to the bottom right corner of the window.rnrnOne such example is the 'Git: Delete branch' command.  I have to click on the branch I want to delete from the drop down selector, then click the notification button far away in the corner to confirm the delete.  If I am deleting multiple branches at a time (because I'm finally cleaning up my local state ud83dude1c) I have to move the mouse back and forth a ton of times so now I use a terminal for this task instead.rnrnIt would be nice to have an option that lets me decide where I want the notifications to appear.  I would choose the top right corner to reduce mouse movement.

issue.title: Welcome page background color
issue.body: Welcome page's background is always set to editor background, while welcome page foreground colors depend on the theme (dark foreground for light theme, light foreground for dark theme). This makes welcome page unreadable in case that you have dark editor background with light theme. The same problem happens for extension documentation page.rnrnWould it be possible to add a setting for welcome page background (it can also apply to extension documentation page and other embedded web pages)? To maintain background compatibility, it can default to editor background when not set.rnrnExamples:rnrn![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/491482/38016402-2cf7df8e-326f-11e8-9431-8e2e87a218c8.png)rnrn![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/491482/38016715-288c9d62-3270-11e8-86f7-a76ed21bb550.png)rn

issue.title: Git: Support an ignored repository list setting
issue.body:
Issue Type: BugrnrnI keep all my dotfiles and settings in [a repo](https://github.com/szhu/important-things), and my `settings.json` is symlinked into that repo. Whenever I open Preferences > Settings, my repo is added to the source control sidebar.rnrnSteps to reproduce on Mac:rnrn0. Quit VSCodern1. `mv '$HOME/Library/Application Support/Code/User' '$HOME/mysyncedusersettings'`rn2. `cd mysyncedusersettings; git init`rn3. `ln -ns '../../../mysyncedusersettings' '$HOME/Library/Application Support/Code/User'`rn4. Open VSCode. The app can be in any state (a project may or may not be open).rn5. Cmd-,rnrnThe settings UI opens -- I would expect opening my settings panel to do only that. What actually happens is that in `mysyncedusersettings` gets added to the source code panel in the sidebar. Sometimes it doesn't appear immediately, but it will always appear after a window reload.rnrnI understand that this can be desirable behavior (and it sometimes is for me actually), but I feel like there should be an option to turn it off, or to open Preferences in a new window so that it doesn't affect the state of the existing window's Git sidebar.rnrnVS Code version: Code 1.21.1 (79b44aa704ce542d8ca4a3cc44cfca566e7720f1, 2018-03-14T14:39:09.335Z)rnOS version: Darwin x64 17.4.0rnrn

issue.title: Pressing escape in the terminal should clear the selection
issue.body: Testing #46594.rnrn1) Select command output that was previously scrolled out of the viewportrn2) Realize you were off by one and selected the wrong outputrn3) Press <kbd>ESC</kbd>rn-> The output is deselected and the terminal scroll to the prompt. If the command was several dozen commands before, I have to go all the way back to correct an off-by-one mistake.rnrnI'm unsure what the right thing is. I'd expect the first <kbd>ESC</kbd> to remove the selection and the second to jump back. But I'm not sure how many flows would break with that.

issue.title: vscode edit bug report
issue.body:
Issue Type: BugrnrnInside the shell command script python is used (using it's full path) to infer the path for the actual script file (rather than the link used to run it):rnrn function realpath() { /usr/bin/python -c 'import os,sys; print(os.path.realpath(sys.argv[1]))' '$0'; }rnrnThis doesn't work when a non-default python exists in the path along wiht a matching PYTHONPATH variablernIn my case, anaconda with python3 and PYTHONPATH=/usr/local/lib:/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packagesrnrnThe script exists with an error:rnYour PYTHONPATH points to a site-packages dir for Python 3.x but you are running Python 2.x!rnrnI edited the script file to use python instead of /usr/bin/python, but this gets overwritten with every minor update, requiring redoing the edit every couple of days.rnrnScript should either not get overwritten with every update if it has not changed or to use relative path (just python instead of /usr/bin/python)rnrnVS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.22.0-insider (ec3c083444c084394ee0cd936074019c1bc0b321, 2018-03-14T06:08:15.960Z)rnOS version: Darwin x64 17.5.0rnrn

issue.title: Predefined snippet choices - in many lines cut intellisense prompt [bug]
issue.body: <!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->rnSteps to Reproduce:rnrnWrite snippets like this:rnrnt'case-of-reduser': {rntt'scope': 'javascript,javascriptreact',rntt'prefix': 'case-of-reducer',rntt'body': [rnttt'case '${2|ACTION_TYPE, ACTION',rnttt'_TYPE2|}':',rnttt'return ${3}',rntt]rnt},rnrnOr this:rnrnt'case-of-reduser': {rntt'scope': 'javascript,javascriptreact',rntt'prefix': 'case-of-reducer',rntt'body': [rnttt'case '${2|ACTION_TYPE, ACTIONn_TYPE2|}':',rnttt'return ${3}',rntt]rnt}rnrnWhere option of choice is in many lines or with `n`.rnWhen use this, intellicence show cut second prompt:rn![snippet-predefined-choices-intellisence-bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16800535/36992386-08201ac6-20ab-11e8-9abb-7cd40b3b848b.png)rnrnThis additional line is added after selecting the second item. You just can not see her in intellisence.rnrnI consider this a bug, because it is possible to create a multi-line predefined-choice in snippets, and intellisence does not adapt to it.rnrnIt's probably best that it displays like ... like whole snippets, in an extra field next to the intellisence list.

issue.title: SnippetString doesn't have builder-method for Choice
issue.body: In the snippet docs there's syntax for adding choices for placeholders:rnrn> # Choicern> Placeholders can have choices as values. The syntax is a comma separated enumeration of values, enclosed with the pipe-character, for example `${1|one,two,three|}`. When the snippet is inserted and the placeholder selected, choices will prompt the user to pick one of the values.rnrnCurrently the `SnippetString` class has methods for `appendPlaceholder`, `appendVariable`, etc. but there isn't an option for choices. We can build these manually, but it'd be better if we could stick to a nice API.

issue.title: Feature Request: Allow snippet json prefix to be an array to support multiple prefixes for the same snippet
issue.body: We have several of the same snippets in our snippets json:rn```jsonrn'Function-Advanced': {rn        'prefix': 'function-advanced',rn        'body': [rn            'function ${1:Verb-Noun} {',rn            't[CmdletBinding()]',rn            'tparam (',rn            'tt$0',rn            't)',rn            't',rn            'tbegin {',rn            't}',rn            't',rn            'tprocess {',rn            't}',rn            't',rn            'tend {',rn            't}',rn            '}'rn        ],rn        'description': 'Script advanced function definition snippet'rn    },rn'Cmdlet': {rn        'prefix': 'cmdlet',rn        'body': [rn            'function ${1:Verb-Noun} {',rn            't[CmdletBinding()]',rn            'tparam (',rn            'tt$0',rn            't)',rn            't',rn            'tbegin {',rn            't}',rn            't',rn            'tprocess {',rn            't}',rn            't',rn            'tend {',rn            't}',rn            '}'rn        ],rn        'description': 'Script cmdlet definition snippet'rn    },rn```rnrnThis could be avoided by supporting an array of prefixes like so:rnrn```jsonrn'Cmdlet': {rn        'prefix': ['function-advanced', 'cmdlet'], // <--- herern        'body': [rn            'function ${1:Verb-Noun} {',rn            't[CmdletBinding()]',rn            'tparam (',rn            'tt$0',rn            't)',rn            't',rn            'tbegin {',rn            't}',rn            't',rn            'tprocess {',rn            't}',rn            't',rn            'tend {',rn            't}',rn            '}'rn        ],rn        'description': 'Script cmdlet definition snippet'rn    }rn```rnrnIt'd help slim down snippet json files and support snippets that might go by different names.

issue.title: Misleading documentation for Position functions
issue.body: In [vscode.d.ts](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/d1fc73226af79c8c4737011300a3ef8720ece4cd/src/vs/vscode.d.ts), the `Position` comparison functions `isBefore`, `isBeforeOrEqual`, `isAfter`, and `isAfterOrEqual` have misleading descriptions. For example, `isBefore` says 'Check if `other` is before this position.' I think it would be more clear to say something like 'Check if this position is before `other`', as that is when `true` is returned. Likewise for the other three.rn

issue.title: Turn off hiding of tree view buttons
issue.body: When a tree view has some extra buttons (e.g., new file in explorer), they only appear when hovering, or focusing the tree view.rnrnCould an option be added to not hide them? Hiding them does not return any space to the user, it simply makes the display a bit cleaner.rnrnIt took me ages to work out where I had once seen the git refresh button in the insiders build because with multiple source control providers another tree view is shown, which means the buttons which are normally on the source control titlebar are now hidden.rnrnPersonnally I think it is unfriendly UI design to make the user have to move their mouse around in order to find buttons.

issue.title: Add TM_FILENAME_BASE snippet variable
issue.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:16:18.034Z)rn- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063rn- Extensions: rnrnExtension|Author (truncated)|Versionrn---|---|---rnaurelia|Aur|0.3.4rnnuget-reverse-package-search|jes|0.1.68rnvscode-nuget-package-manager|jmr|1.1.4rndocomment|k--|0.0.17rnmssql|ms-|1.1.0rncsharp|ms-|1.12.1rnPowerShell|ms-|1.4.1rndebugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.8rnvscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16rnshell-launcher|Tyr|0.1.3rnsort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0rnrnrnrn---rnrnI am adding my own snippets to try to replace what exists in Visual Studio, as much as I can. **I would like a variable such as `TM_FILENAME_BASE`** that does not include any extensions, since that is the default class/etc name for many languages. Or better yet, the ability to apply regex replacement rules to the variables, such as `${TM_FILENAME,/^([A-Z])/L$1/,/([a-z])([A-Z])/$1-L$2/g,/..*$//}`:rnrn  * `TM_FILENAME` - start with the filenamern  * Comma separated regex replacement rulesrn    * `/^([A-Z])/L$1/` - if the first character is uppercase, replace it with lowercasern    * `/([a-z])([A-Z])/$1-L$2/g` - replace all `xY` with `x-y`rn    * `/..*$//` - if the filename ends with an extension, remove itrn  * Thus, `MyCustomElement.html` becomes `my-custom-element`

issue.title: Show project README when opening a project
issue.body: When I open a project in VS Code, I get presented with the Welcome screen. While that screen is nice, I believe it would be even more valuable to present the project's README (or README.md or .txt, whichever is present) in that same screen or even instead of that screen. This way, when you open VS Code without any open project you would be presented with the Welcome screen as it currently is, whereas if you open a project the README would be shown prominently (possibly with some of the shortcuts of the Welcome screen still on the right-hand side or something similar).

issue.title: Add Sync (Rebase)
issue.body: I suggest having a *Sync (Rebase)* option under *Sync*.rnrnMost of the times I find myself having to manually run the two commands simply because sync uses regular pull. I don't want to edit my git configuration to always rebase either.rnrnI think it makes sense to have a *Sync (Rebase)* option since there already is a *Pull (Rebase)*, and sync uses pull.

issue.title: files.autoSave: afterDelay causes distractingly blinking Source Control working indicator

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)rn- OS Version: Windows 7rn---rnrnSteps to Reproduce:rnrn1. Configure 'files.autoSave': 'afterDelay', leave the default delay of 1000 ms.rn2. Initialize an empty git repository in the current directoryrn3. Start editing a file, especially not under source control (so that there's no changed files and no git badge counter on the Source Control icon)rn4. Observe that about once every 5 seconds or so a clock badge briefly appears on the Source Control icon and, if you have Source Control panel open, the blue dash moves above the commit message field.rnrn![vscode-source-control-annoyance](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/308111/27737578-4adbe786-5db1-11e7-94fb-25a893934196.gif)rnrnThats pretty annoying and distracting! It's less noticeable if you're editing a file under source control, since that 'in progress' icon then doesn't appear out of the blue but replaces the number of changed files. It's also less noticeable when you don't have the source control panel open so there's no blue dash.rnrnThe cause is obvious: vscode saves the file you're actively working on every second, after some further delay the git plugin notices that something changed and asks git what exactly (which can be seen in the output console - Git) and while doing that indicates that it's busy.rnrnMaybe just don't do that? Just don't show the busy indicator when routinely rescanning the source folder? And when autofetching too, by the way, if it does that now.

issue.title: Optionally enable --prune while git fetch'ing

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body: Since it is now possible to delete local git branches the remaining problem is that remote-tracking refs are accumulated over time and clutter the checkout and other menus. I think it would make sense if one could enable the `--prune` flag when vscode does it's periodic `git fetch` so that refs which don't exist anymore on the server are automatically cleaned.

issue.title: Bad Markdown rendering of lists in documentation on hover
issue.body: - VSCode Version: 1.12.2, latest 1.13.0-insidersrn- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4rnrnSteps to Reproduce:rnrn1. install the redhat java extensionrn2. open a java filern3. add `import java.util.Map;`rn4. hover over `Map`, scroll to the bottom.rnrnList is not displayed properly. 1st level bullets and content are on separate lines:rnrnrnWhen Markdown Javadoc was introduced last september, this is how it looked:rnrnrnI don't know when the regression was introduced.rnrnThis is the completion item sent to VS Code:rnrn```rn[Trace - 9:38:45 AM] Sending request 'textDocument/hover - (92)'.rnParams: {rn 'textDocument': {rn 'uri': 'file:///Users/fbricon/Dev/souk/aloha/src/main/java/com/redhat/developers/msa/aloha/TracingConfiguration.java'rn },rn 'position': {rn 'line': 4,rn 'character': 18rn }rn}rnrnrn[Trace - 9:38:45 AM] Received response 'textDocument/hover - (92)' in 30ms.rnResult: {rn 'contents': [rn 'An object that maps keys to values. A map cannot contain duplicate keys; each key can map to at most one value.nnThis interface takes the place of the Dictionary class, which was a totally abstract class rather than an interface.nnThe Map interface provides three *collection views*, which allow a map's contents to be viewed as a set of keys, collection of values, or set of key-value mappings. The *order* of a map is defined as the order in which the iterators on the map's collection views return their elements. Some map implementations, like the TreeMap class, make specific guarantees as to their order; others, like the HashMap class, do not.nnNote: great care must be exercised if mutable objects are used as map keys. The behavior of a map is not specified if the value of an object is changed in a manner that affects equals comparisons while the object is a key in the map. A special case of this prohibition is that it is not permissible for a map to contain itself as a key. While it is permissible for a map to contain itself as a value, extreme caution is advised: the equals and hashCode methods are no longer well defined on such a map.nnAll general-purpose map implementation classes should provide two 'standard' constructors: a void (no arguments) constructor which creates an empty map, and a constructor with a single argument of type Map, which creates a new map with the same key-value mappings as its argument. In effect, the latter constructor allows the user to copy any map, producing an equivalent map of the desired class. There is no way to enforce this recommendation (as interfaces cannot contain constructors) but all of the general-purpose map implementations in the JDK comply.nnThe 'destructive' methods contained in this interface, that is, the methods that modify the map on which they operate, are specified to throw UnsupportedOperationException if this map does not support the operation. If this is the case, these methods may, but are not required to, throw an UnsupportedOperationException if the invocation would have no effect on the map. For example, invoking the `putAll(Map)` method on an unmodifiable map may, but is not required to, throw the exception if the map whose mappings are to be 'superimposed' is empty.nnSome map implementations have restrictions on the keys and values they may contain. For example, some implementations prohibit null keys and values, and some have restrictions on the types of their keys. Attempting to insert an ineligible key or value throws an unchecked exception, typically NullPointerException or ClassCastException. Attempting to query the presence of an ineligible key or value may throw an exception, or it may simply return false; some implementations will exhibit the former behavior and some will exhibit the latter. More generally, attempting an operation on an ineligible key or value whose completion would not result in the insertion of an ineligible element into the map may throw an exception or it may succeed, at the option of the implementation. Such exceptions are marked as 'optional' in the specification for this interface.nnMany methods in Collections Framework interfaces are defined in terms of the `equals` method. For example, the specification for the `containsKey(Object key)` method says: 'returns true if and only if this map contains a mapping for a key k such that (key==null ? k==null : key.equals(k)).' This specification should *not* be construed to imply that invoking Map.containsKey with a non-null argument key will cause key.equals(k) to be invoked for any key k. Implementations are free to implement optimizations whereby the equals invocation is avoided, for example, by first comparing the hash codes of the two keys. (The `Object.hashCode()` specification guarantees that two objects with unequal hash codes cannot be equal.) More generally, implementations of the various Collections Framework interfaces are free to take advantage of the specified behavior of underlying `Object` methods wherever the implementor deems it appropriate.nnSome map operations which perform recursive traversal of the map may fail with an exception for self-referential instances where the map directly or indirectly contains itself. This includes the clone(), equals(), hashCode() and toString() methods. Implementations may optionally handle the self-referential scenario, however most current implementations do not do so.nnThis interface is a member of the Java Collections Framework.nn * **See Also:**n n * HashMapn * TreeMapn * Hashtablen * SortedMapn * Collectionn * Setn * **Parameters:**n n * **** the type of keys maintained by this mapn * **** the type of mapped valuesn * **Author:**n n * Josh Blochn * **Since:**n n * 1.2'rn ]rn}rn```rnrnrnrn

issue.title: Bring back ahead/behind counts while git syncing

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body: - VSCode Version: 1.12.0rn- OS Version: Win 10rnrnSteps to Reproduce:rnrn1. Create a commit and click on the sync icon in the bottom leftrn2. Observe how the ahead/behind counts disappear immediately before the operation is donernrnThis change was done in fab6f8871ad234ffe0123265f313458590535119 (@joaomoreno) and it really annoyed me when it was released and still does. It just seems wrong to me and I found it much nicer before. With 1.12.0 the sync icon spins again, but now removing the ahead/behind counts immediately feels weird as the spinning sync operation 'works' on pushing/pulling those two things and only when it's done spinning the counts should disappear as well. I hereby vote for reverting that change, especially since now the icon is spinning again. Thanks! :)

issue.title: Git: Manage the ignore file
issue.body: Git integration is good in vscode but one thing is missing, ignore.rnrnI am running Vscode 1.10.2 on MacOS Sierra 10.12.4.rnrnWorking on a project, I noticed the Git integration had discovered that .DS_Store had changed and was listed with my edited files.rnrnI wanted to tell Git to ignore this file, but found that this option was not among the integrated git commands.  It really should be available.  All that is involved is adding a line to the project .gitignore file.rnrnI then tried to edit the .gitignore file in Vscode, but I found I could not easily open the file.rnOn MacOS it is standard practice to hide system files, including those with names that begin with '.'rnVscode uses the standard Mac open file dialog, which, of course, will not let me see the .gitignore file.rnrnI looked for a way to specify the file path directly, without using the dialog, and could not do so.rnrnPlease, as well as git ignore, could you add the ability to open a file using its explicit path.rnrnI was unable to find either of these addressed in Vscode docs or open issues.rn

issue.title: Move CancellationToken into own npm package
issue.body: JavaScript does not have a native way to represent cancellation of async operaions, and there have been many discussions and failed attempts to fold this into the language. [The most promising tc39 proposal](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-cancelable-promises) has been withdrawn (which used `CancellationToken`s), bluebird has cancellable promises and RxJS Observables are cancellable.rnrnVS Code uses `CancellationToken` from C# for cancellation. They are also used in the TS Server, vscode-jsonrpc and vscode-languageserver. Currently, this comes down to just two classes: `CancellationToken` and `CancellationTokenSource`. These classes seem to be duplicated in the code of every of the above examples. This imposes a problem, because one of the biggest concerns with cancellations is what a promise should resolve to when it is cancelled - typically it is rejected with a `CancelledError`, and code needs to differentiate between a true error and a cancellation in eg `catch` blocks. The TS Server for example does define its own `OperationCancelledException` (which weirdly doesn't inherit from `Error`). If every API defines its own classes and there is no uniform interface, it is impossible to do proper checks for CancellationErrors in catch blocks (eg with `instanceof` or some other type check).rnrnAdding to that, the implementation is lacking basic features that were discussed in the tc39 proposal and available in C#, for example composition of CancelTokens. It is a basic use case to combine multiple CancellationTokens, creating a new CancellationTokenSource from an existing CancellationToken or `throwIfRequested()`.rnrnMoving cancellation into a standalone open source library that anyone could use would greatly improve the interoperability between APIs and allow to easily add more features that improve usage ergonomics.

issue.title: Force quit with the ability to revert changes silently
issue.body: With Vim keybinding extensions, there is a command :q! that is a force quit.rnrnWhen you execute this command it quits, without prompting, and without storing any changes. This is what differentiates it from hotexit, all changes should be **reverted**.rnrnAll prompts should be suppressed and the editor should be closed right away.rnrnCurrently there is nothing in the API to allow us to do this rnrn```:q! to quit without saving (short for :quit!)```rnrnOver at VSCodeVim this is one of our highest rated issues:rnhttps://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/979

issue.title: Add .npmignore as a known file type
issue.body: - VSCode Version: 1.8.1rn- OS Version: Windows 10rnrnIn Windows Explorer, when you choose to always open `.npmignore` files with VS Code, they do not get the code file icon like `.gitignore` does, but just the generic VS Code app icon. Would be nice to add this as a known file type, so those files also get the correct icon.rnrnMeanwhile, here's a registry hack to fix it:rn```rnWindows Registry Editor Version 5.00rnrn[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOTVSCode.npmignore]rn@='NPM Ignore Source File'rn'AlwaysShowExt'=''rnrn[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOTVSCode.npmignoreDefaultIcon]rn@='C:Program Files (x86)Microsoft VS Coderesourcesappresourceswin32code_file.ico'rnrn[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOTVSCode.npmignoreshell]rnrn[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOTVSCode.npmignoreshellopen]rnrn[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOTVSCode.npmignoreshellopencommand]rn@=''C:Program Files (x86)Microsoft VS CodeCode.exe' '%1''rnrn[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT.npmignore]rnrn[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT.npmignoreOpenWithProgids]rn'VSCode.npmignore'=''rn```

issue.title: Navigate to next/previous symbolic match in file
issue.body: Similarly to the navigation in textual matches: The editor could offer navigation between symbolic matches.rnrnE.g., I often find myself with the text cursor on a symbol, looking at the overview ruler to see the other occurrences of that symbol and wanting to navigate through these. Currently I have to use the mouse to click through the other occurrences in the overview ruler, it would be great to have a way to do the same with the keyboard.

issue.body: Feature suggestion:  To default git clone into the `/tmp` folder, or to at least allow settings for a default folder...rnrnI typically use this to dig deeper into Github repos on Atom/VS Code, rather than browsing through their web interface. issue.title: Noticeable delay each time in-product release notes editor is made active.

milestone.title: Backlog

issue.body: - VSCode Version:1.6.0 insidersn- OS Version: WindowsnnSteps to Reproduce:n1. Follow test plan to enable in product release notes in insiders https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12520n2. Help > Release Notesn3. Note delay (~1.5 seconds) when page is initially displayed.n4. Switch to a different editor and then go back to release notes.nnThe release notes editor is re-rendered and there is the same delay each time. nWe should look into caching the rendered page since release notes are unlikely to change during the user's reading of the release notes. issue.title: [CSS] Add specificity to hover
issue.body: Currently when one hovers over a selector in a CSS file it gives a preview of what it selects. This is useful for beginners or if you just forget what a particular selector does.nnWhat would make this even more useful is to also include the specificity of the selector in the preview popup. Many beginners/intermediate don't understand specificity, which is why you often see super specific selectors all over. Even for experts, it would be quicker than calculating yourself for longer selectors.nnExample:nn```n-----------------------------n<select>nu2026n<option :checked>nSpecificity: 0,1,2n-----------------------------nselect option:checkedn```nnNote: I used how CSS2.1 defines specificity. CSS3 Selectors defines it as 012, which I think is confusing as it makes it look like if there were 10 classes or pseudo classes it would be 102 rather than 0102. CSS 4 Selectors shows it as a=0 b=1 c=2.nnCode already exists to calculate specificity in JS if you want to add using 3rd party code https://github.com/keeganstreet/specificityn

Other Editors have the default set to the last open file, which is the second option for VSCode. n- VSCode Version: 1.1.1-insidern- OS Version: Windows 10nnSteps to Reproduce:n1. <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>p</kbd> OR <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>e</kbd>n2. The current file is the first selection. n

issue.body: Extracted from #1586.nRelated: #200.n#### block/block-thin/block-hollow/block-outline:nn![block-outline](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261509/12010563/7443fbae-acb4-11e5-96d3-d29e3a26991c.png)nn``` cssn? {n    background: transparent;n    border: 1px solid;n    box-sizing: border-box;n    position: absolute;n    width: 1ch;n    cursor: text;n}n```n#### block/block-filled:nn![block-filled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261509/12010567/88c493fe-acb4-11e5-8c34-3b606b3ffed9.png)nn``` cssn? {n    position: absolute;n    width: 1ch;n    cursor: text;n}n```n#### line/line-thin/line-narrow:nn![line-thin](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261509/12010569/93a71e68-acb4-11e5-88ae-46d6bace2c3a.png)nn``` cssn? {n    position: absolute;n    width: 1px;n    cursor: text;n}n```n#### line/line-thick/line-accessible:nn![line-thick](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261509/12010570/9fdc7c46-acb4-11e5-926a-063993dee59d.png)nn``` cssn? {n    position: absolute;n    width: 2px;n    cursor: text;n}n```n#### underline/underline-thin:nn![underline-thin](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261509/12010571/aefe6d88-acb4-11e5-8db1-27cf3c1b311a.png)nn``` cssn? {n    background: transparent;n    border-bottom: 1px solid;n    box-sizing: border-box;n    position: absolute;n    width: 1ch;n    cursor: text;n}n```n#### underline/underline-thick/underline-accessible:nn![underline-thick](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261509/12010572/b713d1b6-acb4-11e5-951a-0444b99f0e4d.png)nn``` cssn? {n    background: transparent;n    border-bottom: 2px solid;n    box-sizing: border-box;n    position: absolute;n    width: 1ch;n    cursor: text;n}n```nnI'm not too sure about the names, maybe:nnblock-fillednblock-outlinenline-thinnline-thicknunderline-thinnunderline-thicknn... I'll leave this to the developers. =)nncc @glen-84 @markrendle n

issue.title: Should allow adjusting font weight
issue.body: We have the settings `editor.fontFamily` and `editor.fontSize`, but I'm missing an `editor.fontWeight`. This is most needed when using a dark theme, as folds become visually bolder in that setting. Compare for example Code using Input Mono (regular):nnnnwith Sublime Text using Input Mono Thin:nnnnThis could be either accomplished by a weight setting similar to the CSS `font-weight`, or as part of the font name (i.e. Sublime text accepts 'Input Mono Thin' as the font name, while Code currently rejects that).nn---nnOh, and kudos for creating an editor experience to rival the best on Mac! I never thought the day would come when I'd run a Visual Studio product on Mac, but I'm happy to be proven wrong!n
